If you liked my impromptu thread on how these bad risk metrics get 'accidentally' codified, wait til I post one about radon... (entire Healthy Buildings team collectively rolls their eyes...) https://t.co/d3PluwgnxZ

Great report on schools and uptake of different ventilation/filtration strategies, by current @HarvardChanSPH MPH student @iamanniehoang (also MD student at UCSF) for @mygreenschools. Lots of useful insights. https://t.co/aCzGhNgEYp
Smart take by @juliettekayyem. Public health guidance has to quickly adjust to changing dynamics in US or becomes irrelevant/ignored. https://t.co/4WdhYWWeLS
Side note: this is why I also think things like H-Index are nonsense. There are ways to have impact that go behind citations of your work in peer-reviewed journals. -end-
And then...the VA revised its guidance and DROPPED THE 30% RULE! Same with Allegheny County! https://t.co/Z8ltJx3ihU
There were hearings on this...where they discussed the false sense of security from this "30%" metric https://t.co/8qLU8HrylJ
The VA Inspector General investigated. And, for the first time I'm aware, flagged that this 30% rule may not be all it was cracked up to be, citing our work (!) https://t.co/aKtRELkRBj
Our paper got attention after there was an outbreak in a VA hospital in ....ALLEGHENY COUNTY (!) https://t.co/BCZd0O1fXc

And we published a paper showing this, which I'm pretty sure has 0 citations, but I still think it's one of my most important papers. Because it did have one key, non-academic citation... https://t.co/pXQzN1MUDM
We did a literature review of all outbreaks we could find to formally test this 30% metric. Guess what? it doesn't work. https://t.co/9Ka1ONtWJv
(we cleaned up the handwritten notes for the paper...but notice how much ties into Best et al. and Allegheny) https://t.co/wU2qYRd7Pm
When we dug deeper it just became a web of self-citations, with all of the studies actually only relying on Best et al. (here's us trying to untangle the web!) https://t.co/NcQk2qZhIC

From there it got strange. A few agencies, like the Allegheny County Health Dept, started using this metric, citing Best et al. Then others started to use it, too, citing Allegheny... https://t.co/T3sGJX7SPR

So I started tracing the history of this 30% metric. Turns out it came from a paper in 1983 (Best et al.), where they did an oversimplified analysis and merely *suggested* a 30% cutoff made sense. https://t.co/HHUREQfNQF

Never made sense to me, for obvious reasons (um, what if you took 100 samples and 99 were negative, but there was one positive sample with high levels of L. pneumophila in a bone marrow transplant unit?)

I led the Legionnaires' disease outbreak investigations for my prior firm. And everywhere I went hospitals would cite this '30% cutoff' for determining risk. If <30% of water samples tested positive, ok. If >30%, higher risk.

Incredible paper and team tracing the history of the 6' rule and droplet/aerosol issues. Amazing how thin the basis for some of these things are, yet get codified into our guidance. (I have one non-covid example that is my least-cited, but maybe most important, paper) THREAD https://t.co/tLWXgQNOnU
--> https://t.co/bBwtMpbbsX

Schools closed is a national emergency. Acute crisis - still. https://t.co/nKq4cxfbWw
